sen.j: 離宮八幡宮（りきゅうはちまんぐう）とは京都府乙訓郡大山崎町にある神社。
sen.e: Rikyu Hachiman-gu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Oyamazaki Cho, Otokuni County, Kyoto Prefecture.
Rikyu Hachiman-gu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Oyamazaki Cho, Otokuni County, Kyoto Prefecture.
Rikyu Hachiman-gu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Oyamazaki-cho, Otokuni-gun, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 住所表記を修正しました。

tit.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 石清水八幡宮の元社にあたる神社。
sen.e: Its original shrine was Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine.
Its original shrine was Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine.
Its original shrine was Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine.

sen.j: 大安寺の僧行教が宇佐神宮に参詣した折に「われ都の近くに移座し国家を鎮護せん」と神託をし、嵯峨天皇の離宮跡であるこの地にきた時、霊光を見て、掘ってみると岩間から湧き水が出たという。
sen.e: It is said that when the monk Gyokyo of Daian-ji Temple visited Usa-jingu Shrine, he acted as an oracle and transmitted the message 'move near to the capital for the protection of the state', and that a holy light that he saw at the remains of Emperor Saga's Imperial villa signaled him to dig on the spot from which a spring gushed forth from between the rocks.

It is said that when the monk Gyokyo of Daian-ji Temple visited Usa-jingu Shrine, he acted as an oracle and transmitted the message 'move near to the capital for the protection of the state', and that a holy light that he saw at the remains of Emperor Saga's Imperial villa signaled him to dig on the spot from which a spring gushed forth from between the rocks.

It is said that when the monk Gyokyo of Daian-ji Temple visited Usa-jingu Shrine, he acted as an oracle and transmitted the message 'move near to the capital for the protection of the state', and that a holy light that he saw at the remains of Emperor Saga's Imperial villa signaled him to dig on the spot from which a spring gushed forth from between the rocks.

sen.j: 時の神官が搾油器を発明し「エゴマ」の製油が起こったことで、日本における製油発祥地とされる。
sen.e: The shrine is known as the home of oil production in Japan as the Shinto priest at the time invented an oil press which made it possible to produce perilla oil.
The shrine is known as the home of oil production in Japan as the Shinto priest at the time invented an oil press which made it possible to produce perilla oil.
The shrine is known as the home of oil production in Japan as the Shinto priest at the time invented an oil press which made it possible to produce perilla oil.

sen.j: 「座」の制度で胡麻油の販売権を独占して大いに栄えたという。
sen.e: It flourished due to the monopoly of sesame oil selling rights under the trade guild system.
It flourished due to the monopoly of sesame oil selling rights under the trade guild system.
It flourished due to the monopoly of sesame oil selling rights under the trade guild system.

sen.j: 祭神 応神天皇、神功皇后、酒解大神、比売神
sen.e: The deities enshrined at the shrine are Emperor Ojin, Empress Jingu, Sakatokeno Ookami and Himenokami.
The deities enshrined at the shrine are Emperor Ojin, Empress Jingu, Sakatokeno Ookami and Himenokami.
The deities enshrined at the shrine are Emperor Ojin, Empress Jingu, Sakatoke no okami and Hime no kami.
sen.cmt: "Sakatoke no okami" and "Hime no kami"としました。

sen.j: 近代社格制度 旧府社
sen.e: Classified as a former prefectural shrine under the modern shrine ranking system.
Classified as a former prefectural shrine under the modern shrine ranking system.
Classified as a former prefectural shrine under the modern shrine ranking system.

sen.j: 本殿の神社建築：八幡造
sen.e: Architectural style of the main sanctuary: Hachima-zukuri
Architectural style of the main sanctuary: Hachima-zukuri
Architectural style of the main sanctuary: Hachiman-zukuri

sen.j: 4月3日：日使頭祭（ヒノトウサイ）
武内社、天照皇太神社、蛭子神社、鹿島神社、気比宮、
sen.e: "Shikinaisha" (shrines listed in the Engishiki) include Amaterasu Kotai-jinja Shrine, Ebisu-jinja Shrine, Kashima-jinja Shrine, Kashima-jinja Shrine, Kiinomiya,
"Shikinaisha" (shrines listed in the Engishiki) include Amaterasu Kotai-jinja Shrine, Ebisu-jinja Shrine, Kashima-jinja Shrine, Kashima-jinja Shrine, Kiinomiya,
Takeuchi-sha Shrine, Amaterasu Kotai-jinja Shrine, Ebisu-jinja Shrine, Kashima-jinja Shrine, Kehinomiya Shrine,
sen.cmt: 武内社→"Takeuchi-sha Shrine"に訂正、それに伴い文章を一部修正、Kashima-jinja Shrineの重複分を削除、気比宮→Kehinomiya Shrineに訂正

sen.j: 高天宮神社、小禅師宮、勝手神社、腰掛天神社、高良社など
sen.e: Koten-hu Shrine, Sho Zensi-gu Shrine, Katte-jinja Shrine, Koshikaketen-jinja Shrine, and Kora-sha.
Koten-hu Shrine, Sho Zensi-gu Shrine, Katte-jinja Shrine, Koshikaketen-jinja Shrine, and Kora-sha.

sen.j: 859年 石清水八幡宮として創建。
1864年(元治元年)：禁門の変で被災。
sen.e: 1864: Damaged by fire during the Kinmon Rebellion
1864: Damaged by fire during the Kinmon Rebellion
1864: Damaged by fire during the Kinmon Rebellion
1868: <Edict for Separation of Shinto and Buddhism>
1868: <Edict for Separation of Shinto and Buddhism>
March, 1868: <Edict for Separation of Shinto and Buddhism>

sen.j: 1871年(明治4年)5月14日：＜社格制度制定＞
sen.e: May 14, 1871: <Enactment of the shrine ranking system>

sen.j: 1986年：製油メーカーを中心として「油祖離宮八幡宮崇敬会」が設立される。
sen.e: 1986: 'Oil Founder - Rikyu Hachiman-gu Veneration Association' established with activities mainly focused on oil manufacture.
1986: 'Oil Founder - Rikyu Hachiman-gu Veneration Association' established with activities mainly focused on oil manufacture.
